p.s: The given excerpt shows the final decision of Starr to make her voice the biggest weapon.
Therefore it is written in Starr's point of view to emphasize the importance of the situation and her decision.
The reader only sees limited happenings of the situation but the most important ones for Starr.
ThrougThroughStarrsStarr's eyes and thoughts the reader can relate to her and understand her aims and thoughts.
Starr's state of mind is at a peek where she can decide what to do with her voice and her consciousness.
Her mind is chaotic and needs more space because of the occurancesoccurences that had happened.

She witnesses the death of a close childhood friend named Khalil, she and one of her best friends at Williamsen Prep have a fight going on and the worst that grand jury returned the verdict not to indict Officer Cruise.
That a police officer show a close childhood friend and she herself saw it but everything she tried was not good enough.
This choas in her mind and the fact taht she wants to clear it and use her voice is being shown by narrative techniques and stylistic devices it starts with an allusion.
Black hairbrushes(ll. 2f), which are pointed in the air by the protestors.
This helps the reader to know what is going to happen.

Where it happened(l. 4), a scenic mode, to describe where Starr's mind is in combination with an inner monologue which shows a flashback of the night Khalil was killed (ll. 5-7), makes Starr authentic and closer to the reader it shows the chaos in her head, that she needs to get snapped out of her daze (l. 9).
The crowd yells A hairbrush is not a gun, a phrase that is described as contagious (l. 17).
This phrase is also used like a slogan and seems even more important and strong.
The person who yells the loudest and even holds the bullhorn is Starr's attorney, Ms. Ofrah, who leads the chant (l. 16) and helps Starr find her voice.
Even Seven, DeVante and Chris have rows started saying the slogan which supportsupports that it really is contagious and havehas an even stronger effect on the reader (ll. 16-17).
Starr joins in a stream of consciousness.
At first she mutters which shows her indecisiveness.
This is supported by stream of consciousnesses to give this an even stronger image to the reader.
As soon as Ms. Ofrah sees Starr is making her way over to Starr and states what exactly Starr's most productive weapon is (ll. 26-33).
The fact that Starr's voice is the most effective anand productive weapon shows the protests peacefullnesspeacefulness.
Starr, encouraged by Ms. Ofrah and the protestors uses her voice through the bullhorn.
With the antithetical simile The bullhorn is as heavy as a gun (l. 43) a clear line is made.
It shows the contrast between the peacefullnesspeacefulness of the protestors that is still as heavy and meaningful as the brutality of the police.
This wants the reader to get a negative image of the police and the peacefullnesspeacefulness of the crowd.
The final decision is made in line 48, You know what? Fuck it. At this point, with the scenic mode as a narrative technique, Starr sheds all her anxiety and raises her voice.
She clears her throat, her heart and her mind and has a breakthrough in her character.
The Starr who wanted to be quiet and bluired out is now gone, now she is determindeddetermined and brave.
This is what the reader is meant to understand in this scene.
His live mattered is the last message she wants to give becausbecause even thoughtthough he is dead he too just like any other teenager lived and could have had a family and career.
To give those messages to the reader the excerpt uses many narrative techniques and Starr's point of view.
